questions.question_text: According to the law of demand, what happens to quantity demanded when price rises, all else equal?

options.A: Quantity supplied decreases, causing the market to reach a new equilibrium at a higher output level.
options.B: Quantity demanded increases, reflecting a direct relationship between price and quantity demanded.
options.C: Quantity demanded decreases, reflecting an inverse relationship between price and quantity demanded.
options.D: Quantity demanded remains unchanged because consumer preferences are fixed regardless of price.

questions.question_text: How does a profit-maximizing monopolist determine its output level?

options.A: It produces the quantity where average revenue equals average total cost.
options.B: It produces the quantity where total revenue is maximized regardless of costs.
options.C: It produces the quantity where price equals marginal cost.
options.D: It produces the quantity where marginal revenue equals marginal cost.

questions.question_text: In a market economy, what role do price signals play?

options.A: They replace the need for supply and demand by centrally directing all production decisions.
options.B: They convey information to consumers and producers that guides resource allocation decisions.
options.C: They eliminate competition among sellers by ensuring all firms charge identical amounts.
options.D: They set legally binding limits on the quantities that firms are permitted to produce.

questions.question_text: In a perfectly competitive market, why is each firm considered a price taker?

options.A: Because each firm produces a unique differentiated product and sets its own price above marginal cost.
options.B: Because no individual firm can influence the market price, so each must accept the prevailing price.
options.C: Because the government sets a fixed price that all firms in the industry are required to charge.
options.D: Because a single dominant firm dictates the price and all smaller firms must follow its lead.

questions.question_text: How does economic profit differ from accounting profit?

options.A: Economic profit adds depreciation allowances back to revenue to reflect the true value of assets.
options.B: Economic profit subtracts both explicit costs and implicit opportunity costs from total revenue.
options.C: Economic profit subtracts only explicit cash expenses such as wages, rent, and materials from revenue.
options.D: Economic profit includes government subsidies and tax credits as additional sources of firm revenue.

questions.question_text: In economics, what is market failure?

options.A: A situation in which consumers collectively refuse to purchase goods at any offered price.
options.B: A situation in which the free market allocation of goods and services is not Pareto efficient.
options.C: A situation in which government regulation prevents any voluntary trade from taking place.
options.D: A situation in which too many firms compete, driving all prices below the cost of production.

questions.question_text: How did Lionel Robbins define economics in his influential 1932 essay?

options.A: The science which studies the laws governing monetary policy, banking, and financial institutions.
options.B: The science which studies the accumulation and distribution of national wealth among social classes.
options.C: The science which studies human behavior as a relationship between ends and scarce means which have alternative uses.
options.D: The science which studies the behavior of stock markets, commodity exchanges, and trade balances.

questions.question_text: What does the law of diminishing marginal utility state about consumption?

options.A: Total satisfaction decreases immediately after the very first unit of a good is consumed.
options.B: Each additional unit of a good consumed provides less extra satisfaction than the previous unit.
options.C: Satisfaction per unit remains perfectly constant no matter how many units are consumed.
options.D: Each additional unit of a good consumed provides more extra satisfaction than the previous unit.

questions.question_text: What does the law of diminishing returns state about production?

options.A: Adding more of one input while holding others constant eventually yields smaller increases in output.
options.B: Output always increases at an accelerating rate as additional units of any input are employed.
options.C: Increasing all inputs proportionally always results in a doubling of total output produced.
options.D: Reducing any single input always causes total output to fall by the same proportional amount.

questions.question_text: What is a common effect of a production subsidy on market equilibrium?

options.A: It only shifts the demand curve without changing the supply curve or the equilibrium quantity.
options.B: It eliminates all deadweight loss by perfectly aligning private and social costs of production.
options.C: It increases supply beyond the equilibrium quantity and lowers the market price for consumers.
options.D: It decreases supply below the equilibrium quantity and raises the market price for consumers.

questions.question_text: In microeconomics, what distinguishes a direct tax from an indirect tax?

options.A: A direct tax is paid voluntarily as a charitable contribution while an indirect tax is a mandatory fee charged for using public infrastructure.
options.B: A direct tax is collected by the federal government and an indirect tax is collected by local municipalities, regardless of what is being taxed.
options.C: A direct tax is levied on a person's or organization's income or wealth and cannot be shifted to another party, while an indirect tax is levied on goods or services and can be passed on to consumers through higher prices.
options.D: A direct tax applies only to corporations and an indirect tax applies only to individual consumers based on their household size.

questions.question_text: What is the overjustification effect in the context of incentives?

options.A: It occurs when a government subsidy causes producers to manufacture far more output than the market can efficiently absorb.
options.B: It occurs when consumers purchase more of a product than they actually need because of an unusually large promotional discount.
options.C: It occurs when a firm offers excessively high wages that attract overqualified applicants who then perform below their potential.
options.D: It occurs when providing an external reward for an activity that was already intrinsically motivated reduces the person's intrinsic motivation to perform that activity.

questions.question_text: Why does opportunity cost include both explicit and implicit costs?

options.A: Because explicit costs are borne by the producer and implicit costs are always borne by the consumer, so both must be summed for market analysis.
options.B: Because government regulations require firms to report both categories separately on their annual financial statements and tax filings.
options.C: Because explicit costs arise only in the short run and implicit costs arise only in the long run, so both time horizons must be considered together.
options.D: Because the true cost of a choice encompasses not only direct monetary payments (explicit costs) but also the foregone benefits of the best alternative use of owned resources such as time, labor, or capital (implicit costs).

questions.question_text: How does total revenue change when the price of a good with elastic demand is increased?

options.A: Total revenue becomes unpredictable because elastic demand indicates that consumer preferences are random and unrelated to price changes.
options.B: Total revenue remains unchanged because elastic demand means quantity demanded adjusts proportionally to exactly offset any price change.
options.C: Total revenue decreases because the percentage decline in quantity demanded exceeds the percentage increase in price, so the loss from fewer units sold outweighs the gain from the higher price.
options.D: Total revenue increases because the higher price per unit more than compensates for any reduction in the number of units sold to consumers.

questions.question_text: In a perfectly competitive market, why does a firm's short-run marginal cost curve above average variable cost serve as its supply curve?

options.A: Because a profit-maximizing competitive firm produces where price equals marginal cost, and it will only supply output when the price covers at least its average variable cost; otherwise it shuts down.
options.B: Because government regulations in competitive markets require every firm to set its price exactly equal to its average total cost at all output levels.
options.C: Because marginal cost always decreases with output in competitive markets, ensuring that higher prices lead to proportionally lower quantities supplied.
options.D: Because in perfect competition each firm's demand curve is downward-sloping, so marginal cost determines the quantity consumers are willing to purchase.

questions.question_text: What does the law of diminishing marginal utility state?

options.A: As a consumer's total income rises, the proportion of income spent on luxury goods declines steadily relative to necessity goods.
options.B: As the price of a good decreases, the total utility a consumer derives from that good also decreases proportionally.
options.C: As a firm increases all inputs proportionally, the resulting increase in total output becomes progressively larger over time.
options.D: As a consumer consumes successive units of the same good, holding all else equal, the additional satisfaction gained from each additional unit decreases.

questions.question_text: On a standard supply and demand diagram, how is consumer surplus represented?

options.A: As the triangular area between the supply curve and the demand curve to the right of the equilibrium quantity, representing deadweight loss.
options.B: As the area below the demand curve and above the equilibrium market price, bounded by the quantity axis, representing the aggregate benefit consumers receive by paying less than their maximum willingness to pay.
options.C: As the rectangular area formed by multiplying the equilibrium price by the equilibrium quantity, representing total market revenue.
options.D: As the area above the supply curve and below the equilibrium market price, representing the aggregate benefit producers receive from market transactions.

questions.question_text: What happens to producer surplus when a per-unit tax is imposed on a competitive market?

options.A: Producer surplus remains unchanged because producers always pass the full burden of any tax on to consumers through higher retail prices.
options.B: Producer surplus decreases because the effective price producers receive falls below the original equilibrium price, reducing the gap between the market price received and their minimum willingness to sell.
options.C: Producer surplus is entirely eliminated because the tax forces all producers to sell at exactly their marginal cost of production.
options.D: Producer surplus increases because the tax allows producers to raise their prices by more than the amount of the tax on each unit sold.

questions.question_text: What did John Nash prove about the existence of Nash equilibria in finite games?

options.A: He proved that Nash equilibria exist only when all players have dominant strategies that make them strictly better off regardless of rivals' choices.
options.B: He proved that Nash equilibria exist only in cooperative games where binding agreements among all players can be externally enforced.
options.C: He proved that every finite game has exactly one unique Nash equilibrium in pure strategies, ensuring a single predictable outcome for all players.
options.D: He proved that every finite game, in which each player has a finite set of strategies, has at least one Nash equilibrium, possibly involving mixed strategies where players randomize over their available actions.

questions.question_text: In Pigou's classification of price discrimination, what characterizes first-degree (perfect) price discrimination?

options.A: The seller charges each individual consumer the maximum price that consumer is willing to pay for each unit, thereby capturing the entire consumer surplus as producer revenue.
options.B: The seller offers different product versions at different price points and allows consumers to self-select the version that matches their budget.
options.C: The seller divides consumers into broad demographic groups such as students or seniors and charges each group a different uniform price.
options.D: The seller sets a single price for all consumers but varies the quantity included in each package to appeal to different income levels.

questions.question_text: In Bertrand competition between two firms selling a homogeneous product, what does the model predict about the equilibrium price?

options.A: Both firms set their price equal to marginal cost, replicating the perfectly competitive outcome even with only two sellers.
options.B: Both firms set their price above marginal cost at a level that maximizes their joint profit through tacit coordination.
options.C: Both firms set their price equal to the monopoly price and split the market demand equally between them.
options.D: The firm with the larger market share sets the price first and the smaller firm undercuts it by a fixed percentage.

questions.question_text: When a negative externality is present in a market, how does the socially optimal quantity of output compare to the market equilibrium quantity?

options.A: The socially optimal quantity is lower than the market equilibrium quantity because the social cost exceeds the private cost of production.
options.B: The socially optimal quantity is zero because any production that generates a negative externality is inherently inefficient.
options.C: The socially optimal quantity is equal to the market equilibrium quantity because externalities only affect the distribution of surplus, not total output.
options.D: The socially optimal quantity is higher than the market equilibrium quantity because external costs reduce consumer demand for the product.

questions.question_text: Why do private markets tend to underprovide public goods?

options.A: Because government regulations prohibit private firms from producing goods that are classified as non-excludable by law.
options.B: Because individuals can benefit from the good without paying for it, creating a free-rider problem that undermines voluntary provision.
options.C: Because public goods are always more expensive to produce than private goods, making them unprofitable at any price level.
options.D: Because private firms lack the technical expertise needed to produce goods that are consumed by large numbers of people.

questions.question_text: What does the marginal rate of substitution (MRS) represent on an indifference curve?

options.A: The rate at which a firm can transform one input into another while keeping total production output constant.
options.B: The rate at which total utility increases as a consumer simultaneously adds one unit of each good to their bundle.
options.C: The rate at which a consumer is willing to give up one good in exchange for an additional unit of the other good while maintaining the same level of utility.
options.D: The rate at which the market price of one good changes relative to the market price of the other good over time.

questions.question_text: What does the slope of a consumer's budget line equal in a two-good model?

options.A: The negative ratio of the consumer's total income to the combined prices of both goods (−M/(Px+Py)).
options.B: The negative ratio of the quantity consumed of the horizontal-axis good to the quantity consumed of the vertical-axis good.
options.C: The negative ratio of the price of the good on the horizontal axis to the price of the good on the vertical axis (−Px/Py).
options.D: The negative ratio of the marginal utility of the horizontal-axis good to the marginal utility of the vertical-axis good.

questions.question_text: How does a monopolist create deadweight loss compared to a perfectly competitive market?

options.A: By setting price equal to marginal cost but earning excess profits due to barriers that prevent new firms from entering the market.
options.B: By restricting output below the competitive quantity and charging a price above marginal cost, the monopolist eliminates mutually beneficial trades.
options.C: By charging all consumers the same price as a competitive market but capturing the entire consumer surplus as monopoly profit.
options.D: By producing more output than the competitive quantity and selling at a price below marginal cost to drive out potential entrants.

questions.question_text: What does the First Fundamental Theorem of Welfare Economics state?

options.A: Under certain conditions, a monopolistic market will produce the same allocation of resources as a perfectly competitive market.
options.B: Under certain conditions, government redistribution of resources can always achieve a more equitable outcome than the market.
options.C: Under certain conditions, every Pareto efficient allocation maximizes the sum of all individual utilities in the economy.
options.D: Under certain conditions, every competitive equilibrium allocation is Pareto efficient.

questions.question_text: According to the Coase theorem, why does the initial assignment of property rights not affect the final allocation of resources when transaction costs are zero?

options.A: Because all parties have identical valuations for the resource, so the initial assignment is irrelevant to the final distribution of wealth.
options.B: Because the parties will bargain and trade the rights to whichever party values them most, reaching the same efficient outcome regardless of who held the rights initially.
options.C: Because property rights have no economic value when transaction costs are zero, so neither party has an incentive to hold them.
options.D: Because the government will always reassign property rights to the most productive party through mandatory arbitration proceedings.

questions.question_text: In Akerlof's 'Market for Lemons' model, what mechanism can cause a used car market to collapse?

options.A: Government safety regulations force sellers to disclose all defects, which increases repair costs and raises the price of all used cars.
options.B: Sellers of low-quality cars exit the market because buyers can easily detect defects, leaving only overpriced high-quality cars for sale.
options.C: Buyers collude to offer prices below the true value of all cars, forcing both high-quality and low-quality sellers to exit simultaneously.
options.D: Buyers cannot distinguish high-quality cars from low-quality ones, so they offer only an average price, causing sellers of high-quality cars to withdraw from the market.

questions.question_text: Why do insurance companies use deductibles and co-payments in their policies?

options.A: To reduce moral hazard by ensuring that the insured party bears part of the cost of a loss, discouraging excessive risk-taking behavior.
options.B: To increase adverse selection by screening out low-risk individuals who are unwilling to pay any out-of-pocket expenses.
options.C: To maximize the insurer's total revenue by collecting additional fees beyond the standard premium from every policyholder.
options.D: To comply with government regulations that require a minimum level of cost-sharing between insurers and all policyholders.

questions.question_text: In the principal-agent problem, what is the term for the divergence between the agent's actions and the principal's best interests?

options.A: Transaction costs, which arise because the principal must pay brokerage fees each time the agent executes a trade on the principal's behalf.
options.B: Opportunity costs, which arise because the principal forgoes alternative investments whenever the agent allocates capital to a specific project.
options.C: Agency costs, which arise because the agent may pursue self-interested behavior due to asymmetric information and the principal's inability to fully monitor the agent's actions.
options.D: Sunk costs, which arise because the principal has already invested resources in hiring the agent and cannot recover those expenditures.

questions.question_text: A price ceiling set below the market equilibrium price will most directly cause which of the following effects?

options.A: A shortage of the good, because the quantity demanded at the ceiling price exceeds the quantity supplied.
options.B: A decrease in demand, because consumers will perceive the price-controlled good as lower quality than unregulated alternatives.
options.C: An increase in the equilibrium price, because consumers will bid up prices in anticipation of future regulation.
options.D: A surplus of the good, because producers will increase output to take advantage of the government-mandated price.

questions.question_text: Revealed preference theory, pioneered by Paul Samuelson in 1938, infers consumer preferences from which of the following?

options.A: Observed purchasing behavior, on the assumption that a consumer's choices reveal their underlying preferences without requiring direct measurement of utility.
options.B: Responses to hypothetical survey questions about willingness to pay, which allow economists to estimate utility functions directly.
options.C: Laboratory experiments in which consumers rank bundles of goods under controlled conditions without any budget constraint.
options.D: Introspective self-reports of satisfaction levels that consumers submit to government statistical agencies after each purchase.

questions.question_text: A Giffen good violates the law of demand because, when its price rises, the quantity demanded increases. Which mechanism explains this paradox?

options.A: The good has perfectly elastic supply, so producers flood the market and consumers stockpile units in anticipation of further price increases.
options.B: The good is so strongly inferior that the income effect of the price increase (which raises demand for the cheap staple) more than offsets the substitution effect (which would reduce demand).
options.C: The good is a complement to a normal good whose price has simultaneously decreased, causing consumers to buy more of both goods together.
options.D: The good is a luxury item whose higher price signals greater quality, causing status-conscious consumers to purchase more of it.

questions.question_text: Compensating variation (CV), introduced by John Hicks in 1939, measures the amount of money needed to do what after a price change?

options.A: Equalize the marginal utilities of all goods in the consumer's basket, ensuring that the last dollar spent on each good yields identical satisfaction.
options.B: Return the consumer to their original utility level at the new prices, representing the monetary compensation required to offset the welfare impact of the price change.
options.C: Bring the consumer to their new utility level at the old prices, representing the monetary gain the consumer would accept to forgo the price change entirely.
options.D: Restore the original quantities consumed before the price change, regardless of whether the consumer's utility level has increased or decreased.

questions.question_text: In the Stackelberg competition model, developed by Heinrich von Stackelberg in 1934, what distinguishes it from the Cournot duopoly model?

options.A: Both firms enter the market at the same time but compete on product differentiation rather than on the quantity of a homogeneous good.
options.B: One firm (the leader) commits to a quantity first and the other firm (the follower) observes this choice before deciding its own quantity, creating a sequential rather than simultaneous game.
options.C: Both firms set prices simultaneously rather than quantities, and the firm with the lower price captures the entire market demand.
options.D: Firms collude explicitly to maximize joint profits and then divide the resulting monopoly output equally between them.

questions.question_text: A natural monopoly arises in an industry primarily because of which cost characteristic?

options.A: A single firm holds an exclusive government patent that legally prevents any other firm from producing the same good for a fixed period.
options.B: A single firm can supply the entire market at a lower long-run average cost than multiple competing firms, due to high fixed costs and large economies of scale relative to market size.
options.C: A single firm controls the entire supply of a scarce natural resource that no other firm can access or synthesize artificially.
options.D: A single firm has the lowest marginal cost in the industry because it pays its workers below-market wages through monopsony power.

questions.question_text: Arrow's impossibility theorem, proved by Kenneth Arrow in 1950, demonstrates which fundamental limitation of ranked-choice voting systems?

options.A: No ranked-choice voting rule can simultaneously satisfy unrestricted domain, Pareto efficiency, independence of irrelevant alternatives, and non-dictatorship when there are three or more alternatives.
options.B: No ranked-choice voting rule can guarantee that the winning candidate is also the most preferred by the median voter in a one-dimensional policy space.
options.C: No ranked-choice voting rule can prevent a candidate who receives fewer than 50 percent of first-place votes from winning the election.
options.D: No ranked-choice voting rule can produce a transitive social ordering when voters are allowed to express indifference between two or more candidates.

questions.question_text: The 2007 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences was awarded to Leonid Hurwicz, Eric Maskin, and Roger Myerson for foundational contributions to which field?

options.A: Behavioral economics, which studies how cognitive biases and psychological heuristics cause individuals to deviate from rational decision-making.
options.B: Mechanism design theory, which studies how to construct rules or institutions that produce desirable outcomes even when the designer does not know the participants' private information.
options.C: Public choice theory, which studies how self-interested behavior by politicians and bureaucrats influences government policy decisions.
options.D: General equilibrium theory, which studies how prices simultaneously clear all markets in an economy with many interacting consumers and producers.

questions.question_text: What does the Myerson-Satterthwaite theorem establish about bilateral trade under asymmetric information?

options.A: Bilateral trade under asymmetric information always converges to the competitive equilibrium price as the number of rounds of bargaining approaches infinity.
options.B: There is always a posted-price mechanism that achieves full efficiency in bilateral trade as long as the buyer's valuation is drawn from a uniform distribution.
options.C: Any bilateral trade mechanism that satisfies incentive compatibility must also generate a budget surplus that can be redistributed to achieve Pareto improvements.
options.D: There is no mechanism that can simultaneously achieve ex-post efficiency, individual rationality, and incentive compatibility in bilateral trade when both the buyer and seller have private valuations drawn from overlapping distributions.

questions.question_text: The Myerson–Satterthwaite theorem (1983) is a fundamental impossibility result in mechanism design concerning bilateral trade under asymmetric information. What does the theorem prove is impossible when the buyer's and seller's valuation ranges overlap?

options.A: No mechanism can achieve any gains from trade whatsoever, because the buyer and seller will always misrepresent their valuations.
options.B: No mechanism can simultaneously satisfy incentive compatibility, individual rationality, strong budget balance, and ex-ante Pareto efficiency.
options.C: No mechanism can guarantee that the item is traded at a price between the buyer's and seller's valuations without subsidies from a third party.
options.D: No mechanism can simultaneously satisfy incentive compatibility, individual rationality, weak budget balance, and ex-post Pareto efficiency.

questions.question_text: Auction theory identifies four classical single-item auction formats. In a Vickrey auction (sealed-bid second-price auction), what is the dominant strategy for each bidder, and why?

options.A: Each bidder's dominant strategy is to bid slightly above their true valuation, because the winner pays the second-highest bid and a higher bid guarantees winning without affecting the price paid.
options.B: Each bidder's dominant strategy is to bid half their true valuation, because the winner pays their own bid and shading by half maximizes expected surplus.
options.C: Each bidder's dominant strategy is to bid their true valuation, because the winner pays only the second-highest bid, so overbidding risks paying more than one's value while underbidding risks losing a profitable trade.
options.D: Each bidder's dominant strategy is to bid the average of their valuation and the expected second-highest valuation, because this balances the probability of winning against the expected payment.

questions.question_text: The Vickrey–Clarke–Groves (VCG) mechanism is a truthful mechanism for maximizing social welfare. Under the Clarke pivot rule, how is each agent's payment calculated?

options.A: Each agent pays the difference between their own reported valuation and the second-highest reported valuation, analogous to the Vickrey auction payment rule.
options.B: Each agent pays their own reported valuation for the chosen outcome, minus a rebate proportional to the total number of agents in the mechanism.
options.C: Each agent pays the average of all other agents' reported valuations, weighted by the probability that each alternative would have been chosen without the agent.
options.D: Each agent pays the externality they impose: the total welfare of other agents had the agent been absent, minus the total welfare of other agents given the agent's presence.

questions.question_text: Hotelling's law, proposed by Harold Hotelling in his 1929 paper "Stability in Competition," describes spatial competition between firms. What does the principle of minimum differentiation predict for two firms choosing locations on a linear market with uniformly distributed consumers?

options.A: Both firms will locate at opposite ends of the market to maximize their local monopoly power, each capturing half the consumers with minimal competition.
options.B: One firm will locate at the center and the other at an endpoint, with the central firm capturing three-quarters of the consumers.
options.C: Both firms will locate at the first and third quartile points to minimize average consumer travel distance, which also happens to maximize their joint profits.
options.D: Both firms will locate next to each other at the center of the market, each capturing half the consumers, even though the socially optimal locations would be at the first and third quartile points.

questions.question_text: The Slutsky equation, named after Eugen Slutsky, is a fundamental identity in consumer theory. What does it decompose, and what is the sign of the substitution effect?

options.A: It decomposes the total effect of an income change on Hicksian (compensated) demand into a substitution effect and a price effect; the substitution effect is always non-negative.
options.B: It decomposes the total effect of a price change on Marshallian (uncompensated) demand into a substitution effect and an income effect; the substitution effect is always non-positive (negative for strict convexity).
options.C: It decomposes the total effect of a price change on Hicksian demand into a substitution effect and a cross-price effect; the substitution effect is always positive for normal goods.
options.D: It decomposes the total effect of a price change on Marshallian demand into an endowment effect and a wealth effect; the substitution effect can be positive or negative depending on the good.

questions.question_text: The folk theorem in game theory, with early formalization by Friedman (1971), characterizes equilibrium payoffs in infinitely repeated games. What does the theorem state about the set of achievable equilibrium payoff profiles when the discount factor $\delta$ approaches 1?

options.A: Only the Nash equilibrium payoff profile of the stage game can be sustained as a subgame-perfect equilibrium, regardless of the discount factor.
options.B: Only Pareto efficient payoff profiles can be sustained as subgame-perfect equilibria, because patient players always coordinate on the socially optimal outcome.
options.C: Any feasible payoff profile that strictly dominates the minimax payoff profile for every player can be sustained as a subgame-perfect Nash equilibrium of the infinitely repeated game.
options.D: Any feasible payoff profile, including those below the minimax payoff for some players, can be sustained as a Nash equilibrium provided the discount factor is sufficiently close to 1.

questions.question_text: A signaling game is a dynamic Bayesian game in which an informed sender transmits a costly signal to an uninformed receiver. What are the three main types of perfect Bayesian equilibrium that can arise in such games?

options.A: Cooperative equilibria (sender and receiver jointly maximize surplus), non-cooperative equilibria (each player maximizes independently), and mixed equilibria (sender randomizes uniformly across all signals).
options.B: Dominant-strategy equilibria (each type has a unique best signal), correlated equilibria (signals are coordinated by a mediator), and trembling-hand equilibria (types randomize due to small probability of error).
options.C: Nash equilibria (both players best-respond simultaneously), sequential equilibria (beliefs are consistent with strategies on and off the equilibrium path), and Bayesian equilibria (players maximize expected utility given prior beliefs).
options.D: Separating equilibria (different sender types choose different signals), pooling equilibria (all types choose the same signal), and semi-separating (partial pooling) equilibria (some types pool while others separate).

questions.question_text: Screening in economics is a strategy used by the uninformed party to elicit private information from the informed party. How does screening differ from signaling, and what is a canonical example from insurance markets studied by Rothschild and Stiglitz?

options.A: In screening, a regulator mandates information disclosure by all parties, whereas in signaling, the informed party voluntarily discloses; Rothschild and Stiglitz showed that government-mandated risk classes eliminate adverse selection.
options.B: In screening, the uninformed party (e.g., insurer) designs a menu of contracts to induce self-selection, whereas in signaling, the informed party initiates the action; Rothschild and Stiglitz showed insurers offer menus of policies with different deductible-premium combinations to separate high-risk from low-risk customers.
options.C: In screening, the informed party reveals information through costly actions, whereas in signaling, the uninformed party sets a fixed price; Rothschild and Stiglitz showed insurers charge all customers the same premium based on average risk.
options.D: In screening, the uninformed party randomly audits the informed party's claims, whereas in signaling, the informed party invests in reputation; Rothschild and Stiglitz showed insurers use experience rating based solely on past claims history.

questions.question_text: Michael Spence's 1973 job-market signaling model demonstrates how education can serve as a signal of worker ability even if it does not enhance productivity. What critical assumption makes the signal credible, and what characterizes the separating equilibrium?

options.A: The benefit of education is positively correlated with ability (more productive for high-ability workers); in the separating equilibrium, all workers acquire the same level of education but high-ability workers receive higher wages based on test scores.
options.B: The cost of acquiring education is identical for all workers but its return varies; in the separating equilibrium, employers offer a single wage and workers self-select into educated and uneducated groups based on risk preferences.
options.C: The cost of acquiring education is negatively correlated with ability; in the separating equilibrium, employers cannot distinguish workers and pay the average productivity as wages to all educated workers.
options.D: The cost of acquiring education is negatively correlated with ability (cheaper for high-ability workers); in the separating equilibrium, high-ability workers acquire education at or above a threshold level while low-ability workers do not, and employers pay accordingly.

questions.question_text: General equilibrium theory, formalized in the Arrow–Debreu–McKenzie model of the 1950s, studies simultaneous equilibrium across all markets in an economy. What do the First and Second Fundamental Welfare Theorems state, and what mathematical tool is used to prove the existence of equilibrium?

options.A: The First Welfare Theorem states that any competitive equilibrium is Pareto efficient; the Second states that Pareto efficient allocations are unique. Existence is proved using the intermediate value theorem applied to excess demand.
options.B: The First Welfare Theorem states that any competitive equilibrium is Pareto efficient; the Second states that any Pareto efficient allocation can be supported as a competitive equilibrium after appropriate redistribution of endowments. Existence is proved using fixed-point theorems (Brouwer or Kakutani).
options.C: The First Welfare Theorem states that any competitive equilibrium maximizes total surplus; the Second states that every surplus-maximizing allocation is a competitive equilibrium. Existence is proved using the separating hyperplane theorem.
options.D: The First Welfare Theorem states that equilibria are unique under convex preferences; the Second states that equilibria are globally stable under gross substitutes. Existence is proved using the implicit function theorem.
